stem: A 32-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted after spending the day working outdoors in 98°F heat. Based on the documentation in the Environmental Exposure & Fluid Balance Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status changes following heat exposure.
Background: Taking Lithium Carbonate 450mg BID. Athlete and landscaper.
Assessment: Client is dizzy, reporting severe nausea, and has visible 'coarse' hand tremors.
Recommendation: Fluid resuscitation and lithium level check.

tabs.title: Environmental Exposure & Fluid Log
tabs.content:

Daily Intake800 mL (Low for heat)Inadequate hydration
Serum Lithium2.2 mEq/LCritical High (> 1.5)
Serum Sodium152 mEq/L (High)Hypernatremic Dehydration

conditionOptions.text: Heat Exhaustion with Normal Lithium Levels

actionOptions.text: Administer IV 0.9% Normal Saline for rapid volume expansion
Withhold all further doses of Lithium until level is < 1.2
Instruct the client to significantly reduce salt intake to drop sodium
Administer an extra dose of Lithium to stabilize mood during stress

parameterOptions.text: Serum Lithium and Electrolyte levels (Sodium focus)
Urine output and specific gravity monitoring
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Brudzinski sign

rationale.correct: This client has Dehydration-Induced Lithium Toxicity (c2) (Level 2.2). Lithium is a salt; as the patient lost fluids and salt through sweating (leaving him hypernatremic/dehydrated), the kidneys retained Lithium instead of excreting it. The priority is to stop the drug (a2) and rehydrate with Normal Saline (a1) to return the patient to an isovolemic state, which will allow the kidneys to flush the lithium. Monitoring sodium/lithium levels (p1) and urine markers (p2) is essential.
clinicalPearls: Lithium and Sodium share 'transporters' in the kidney. If the body is thirsty for salt/water, it will grab Lithium as if it were sodium.
Vigorous exercise, sweating, and diuretic use are major risk factors for Lithium toxicity.
Coarse tremors always indicate toxicity (Fine tremors are side effects).

questionTrap.trap: Restricting sodium to treat the high sodium (152) in a lithium patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sodium restriction will make the Lithium toxicity even WORSE. Use IV Normal Saline (which has sodium) to restore balance and promote lithium excretion.
